title-group.article-title: Impact of Relative Humidity on Thermal Comfort in a Warm Environment

article-meta.aff: aFaculty of Urban Construction and Environmental Engineering, Chongqing University, Chongqing, PR China
bKey Laboratory of the Three Gorges Reservoir Region’s Eco-Environment, Ministry of Education, Chongqing University, Chongqing, PR China

author-notes.corresp: Baizhan Li, Faculty of Urban Construction and Environmental Engineering, Chongqing University, Chongqing 400045, PR China. Tel. +0086 23 65127531, Fax +0086 23 65127532, E-Mail baizhanli09@gmail.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2013 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav
permissions.copyright-holder: International Society of the Built Environment

abstract.p: Relative humidity is an important environmental factor that could affect thermal comfort in a building. The influence of relative humidity on thermal comfort was studied in an environment chamber. Twenty subjects, ten males and ten females, were engaged in the study and were exposed to nine combinations of air temperature and relative humidity. Skin temperatures on different parts of the body were monitored, and their thermal sensation was evaluated by questionnaire while their thermal environments were measured during the chamber tests. These results were evaluated by statistical analyses which indicate that for higher temperature, relative humidity could have a significant effect on skin temperature and thermal sensation. Higher humidity could cause a negative effect on the subject’s thermal comfort. To avoid causing discomfort, the relative humidity limit should be taken into consideration and there should be a humidity limit specified by the appropriate building code for the acceptable air temperature range to allow an appropriate control of indoor environment.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Relative humidity (RH) is an important thermal environment parameter that could have a significant effect on human physiology response and thermal sensation [1]. The effect has long been recognised, and is included in the effective temperature (ET) scale for evaluation of thermal comfort zone [2]. The ET would give considerable importance to the effect of humidity in a cooler environment where people felt slightly cool or cool, but attributed insufficient importance to the effect of humidity in warm environments where people felt warm (“slightly warm, “warm”); which was not corroborated by other studies [3]. New ET and standard effective temperature (SET*) scales were then developed by ASHRAE [3]. These indices were once adopted as part of ASHRAE standard 55-1992 for evaluating humidity [4], however, have not been used in the current version (ASHRAE 55-2010) [5].

The effect of humidity on thermal sensation is modest when the air temperature is within the comfort range [3]. In previous studies [3,6], the relative humidity in warm conditions was reported to have an effect on the evaporative heat loss from the human skin, thus would also affect thermal sensation. The influence of relative humidity on physiology and thermal sensation has been conducted both under steady state [7,8] and under transient conditions [9–11]. In modest environments, the effect of humidity on thermal sensation could be ignored when the air temperature is in the comfort range [12,13]. In warm environments, discomfort may be caused by too much moisture on skin by high humidity levels. Experimental studies have shown that the skin humidity is a major reason for discomfort at high humidity [14–16]. Many models [17–19] have been developed to predict the physiological conditions affected by relative humidity. For example, Toftum et al. [17] presented the skin humidity model which was applied for assessment of sedentary and thermally neutral persons. And the respiratory model was presented by Toftum et al. [18] for the prediction of the percentage of persons dissatisfied due to the insufficient respiratory cooling. Toftum and Fanger [20] pointed out that the humidity limit developed based on skin humidity was less restrictive and the humidity limit based on respiratory comfort was far more restrictive comparing to the upper humidity limit that was specified in existing thermal comfort standards. However, these studies could not give a precise upper and lower limit of humidity for the comfort zones [4].

The ISO 7730-2005 [21] standard gives a general guidance. ASHRAE 55-2010 [5] does not specify a minimum humidity level for thermal comfort. Furthermore, ASHRAE 55-2010 requires a humidity limit for determining acceptable operative temperatures for naturally conditioned spaces. The Chinese indoor air quality standard (GB 18883-2002) [22] specifies a relative humidity of 40% to 80% for HVAC buildings in summer. The provision of a range of relative humidity is so vague and not specific enough that engineers might find problem to make a correct choice during design and operation of buildings. There is not sufficient explanation of the effect of relative humidity obtained by field studies which are being adopted by the standard [23].

The summary of previous studies of humidity and comfort shows that conclusive results are not often found. In addition, almost no papers reported the effects of RH on thermal sensation of building occupants in China, where the climate is extremely diverse and variable with a tropical climate in the south and a sub-arctic one in the north, including the wide ranges of relative humidity. The Hot Summer and Cold Winter zone and Hot Summer and Warm Winter zone in China is characterised by the moist year-round climate in this region [24,25]. Many studies [26–32] conducted in humidity area show that the relative humidity may be an important factor that could affect human thermal comfort and the choice of climatic control strategies of indoor thermal environment in warm environment [24].

In order to verify how the relative humidity can affect occupants’ response in warm environments, experiments were conducted in a climate chamber. The skin temperature (mean and at local sites), which is one of the physiological indexes used by many thermal comfort studies to reflect the thermoregulation of people [1,32–35], and was adopted by this study to evaluate physiological condition and thermal sensation.

sec.title: Experimental Design
sec.p: The experiment was conducted in an artificial climate chamber (4 × 3 × 2.5 m3, L × W × H) at Chongqing University in Chongqing, China. The air temperature was maintained at three different levels: 26℃, 28℃ and 30℃. These were taken to obtain the mean radiant air temperature, which is equalled to the air temperature. The air velocity was kept near 0.1 m·s−1. The relative humidity was kept at three different levels: 40%, 60% and 80%.

Twenty subjects were recruited to participate in the experiment. All the subjects were young, healthy and did not suffer from any known illnesses or were not taking medication of any type. The subjects were required to wear uniform normal summer clothing with a clo value of about 0.3, such as short sleeve shirts, shorts and lightweight shoes.
A comprehensive thermal environment acquisition system was used to measure thermal environmental parameters around subjects and was positioned at a height of 1.1 m from the floor.

All sensor probes for measuring ambient temperature (Ta), black-bulb temperature (Tg), relative humidity (RH) and air velocity (V) were in conformity with the ISO 7726-2001 standard [36]. Specifications of the sensor probes employed in this study are shown in Table 1. Table 1
Specifications of sensors for measurement of indoor climatic parameters
Parameter Sensor Accuracy
Air temperature Psychrometer ±0.1℃
Global temperature Radiant temperature sensor ±0.15℃
Relative humidity Psychrometer ±1% (40–70%)
±0.5% (70–98%)
Air velocity Hot wire anemometer ±0.04 m·s−1

The copper-constantan thermocouples were attached to the different local skin positions to measure the local skin temperatures, including forehead, chest, back, upper arm (right and left), lower arm (right and left), dorsal hand (right and left), calf (right and left), and thigh (right and left). All the thermocouples were calibrated using a standard mercury thermometer with a precision of 0.1℃; these were linked to a multi-channel data collector which recorded the skin temperatures automatically.

Each experimental session lasted for 1.5 h. During the first 30 min of each session, the subjects were asked to sit quietly in the chamber to adapt to the thermal environment. Once the subjects adapted to the environmental condition set for the test, the test began and lasted for 1 h. The experimental conditions used for the study are as shown in Table 2. Table 2
Thermal environment parameters
Experimental session Ta (℃) Tg (℃) RH (%) V (m·s−1)
1 25.9 ± 0.2 25.70 ± 0.14 41.6 ± 1.5 0.1 ± 0.05
2 25.9 ± 0.1 25.58 ± 0.10 60.0 ± 1.2 0.1 ± 0.06
3 26.0 ± 0.1 25.60 ± 0.12 80.3 ± 2.8 0.1 ± 0.05
4 28.0 ± 0.1 27.60 ± 0.14 40.9 ± 2.0 0.1 ± 0.03
5 27.9 ± 0.1 27.50 ± 0.12 59.7 ± 1.1 0.1 ± 0.03
6 28.0 ± 0.2 27.60 ± 0.22 79.9 ± 2.8 0.1 ± 0.04
7 29.9 ± 0.2 29.40 ± 0.17 41.9 ± 3.5 0.1 ± 0.02
8 29.9 ± 0.1 29.50 ± 0.16 59.9 ± 2.9 0.1 ± 0.03
9 29.9 ± 0.2 29.40 ± 0.15 81.3 ± 1.6 0.1 ± 0.05

During exposure of the subjects to each test condition, the subjects were asked about their perceptions on humidity sensation, thermal sensation, and thermal perception at every 10-min interval. The questionnaire thermal response is shown in Figure 1. The subjects were allowed to rest or to read or undertake other sedentary activity after completion of one set of questionnaire. The subjects should be ready for the next session after their rest. Figure 1
Thermal response questionnaire.

In this study, an 8-point weighted method [2] was adopted to calculate the mean skin temperature (MST), as represented by Equation (1). (1)MST=0.0 7Tforehead+0.175Tchest+0.175Tback +0.0 7Tupper arm+0.0 7Tlower arm +0.0 5Thand+0.19Tthigh+0.2 0Tcalf
where MST is the mean skin temperature calculated according to the measuring sites and the corresponding weighting factors; Tforehead the skin temperature of forehead; Tchest the skin temperature of chest; Tback the skin temperature of back; Tupper arm the average skin temperature of right upper arm and left one; Tlower arm the average skin temperature of right lower arm and left one; Thand the average skin temperature of right dorsal hand and left one; Tthigh the average skin temperature of right thigh and left one; Tcalf the average skin temperature of right calf and left one.

The maximum differences in local skin temperatures between any two local positions (MDLST), is represented by Equation (2). (2)MDLST=Maxium (Tforehead,Tchest,Tback,Tupper arm, Tlower arm,Thand,Tthigh,Tcalf) -Minimum (Tforehead,Tchest,Tback,Tupper arm, Tlower arm,Thand,Tthigh,Tcalf)
where MDLST is the maximum differences in local skin temperatures between any two local positions.

SPSS 18.0 software was used for the statistical analysis and multiple comparisons of the subjects’ responses for the conditions exposed. Differences at p<0.05 were considered significant for all statistical analysis.

sec.title: Objective Measurements
sec.p: The experimental conditions were measured and verified for each set of exposure experiment as shown in Table 2.
The mean radiant temperature was calculated using Equation (3) [36]: (3)Tr=[(Tg+273)4+2.5×108×v0.6(Tg-Ta)]1/4-273

According to the ISO 7726-2001 standard [36], in practical cases where the relative velocity is small (<0.2 m·s−1) or where the difference between mean radiant and air temperature is small (<4℃), the operative temperature can be calculated with a sufficient approximation as the mean value of air and mean radiant temperature. These results are shown in Table 3. Anthropometric data for the subjects are listed in Table 4. Table 3
Mean radiant temperature and operative temperature
Experimental session Tr (℃) Top (℃)
1 25.44 ± 0.23 25.70 ± 0.10
2 25.36 ± 0.19 25.64 ± 0.10
3 25.30 ± 0.22 25.70 ± 0.12
4 27.40 ± 0.18 27.70 ± 0.14
5 27.30 ± 0.13 27.60 ± 0.11
6 27.40 ± 0.20 27.70 ± 0.20
7 29.20 ± 0.23 29.50 ± 0.16
8 29.20 ± 0.22 29.60 ± 0.15
9 29.20 ± 0.20 29.60 ± 0.12
Table 4
Anthropometric data of the subjects
Gender Number of subjects Age (years)* Height (m)* Weight (kg)*
Females 10 23.9 ± 1.0 1.59 ± 0.05 47.8 ± 5.8
Males 10 23.5 ± 1.3 1.75 ± 0.05 67.1 ± 8.8
*Mean ± SD.

sec.title: Physiological Responses
sec.p:
The mean skin temperatures (MST) under different experimental conditions are shown in Figure 2. The MST could be affected both by air temperature and relive humidity. Figure 2
Mean skin temperature among experimental conditions.

The multiple comparisons of MST under different relative humidity were listed in Table 5. Results of the statistical analyses, multiple comparisons reveal that the mean skin temperature at 80% RH/30℃ was significantly the highest among all the experimental conditions. Table 5
Multiple comparisons of mean skin temperature under different ambient temperatures and relative humidity
Air temperature (℃) Relative humidity (%) Relative humidity (%) Mean skin temperature TSV TCV HSV
26 40 60 * 0.498 0.186 *
80 * * * *
60 40 * 0.498 0.186 *
80 0.831 * * *
80 40 * * * *
60 0.831 * * *
28 40 60 * * * *
80 0.801 * * *
60 40 * * * *
80 * * * *
80 40 0.801 * * *
60 * * * *
30 40 60 0.642 * * 0.184
80 * * * *
60 40 0.642 * * 0.184
80 * * * *
80 40 * * * *
60 * * * *
“*”denotes significant difference (p < 0.05), values are post hoc tests, which indicate non-significant influence.

The MDLST could indicate a range of skin temperatures of different human positions [31,33], are shown in Figure 3. The MDLST could be markedly reduced as the air temperature become warmer. At 80% RH, the MDLST was the lowest among the three air temperature levels. Figure 3
Mean maximum differences in local skin temperatures between any two local positions with different air temperatures and relative humidity.

sec.title: Thermal Sensation
sec.p:
The mean value of thermal sensation votes (MTSV) versus air temperature for each relative humidity conditions are shown in Figure 4. From the curve, the MTSV value was shown to increase with a rise in air temperature. At 80% RH, the MTSV value would increase more quickly than at 60% RH and 40% RH. Moreover, multiple comparisons reveal that there was a significant difference in thermal sensation that was reported between the three RH conditions at 30℃ (Table 5). Furthermore, the higher relative humidity could cause participants to feel significantly warmer in warm environments. Figure 4
Mean thermal sensation vote with different air temperatures and relative humidity.

sec.title: Humidity Sensation
sec.p:
As shown in Figure 5, the mean humidity sensation votes (MHSV) at 80% RH were significantly higher than at 40% RH and 60% RH among all air temperature conditions. The MHSV was near 0, which means that the humidity of the environment was felt at neutral, except at the condition of 80% RH and 30℃. Furthermore, MHSV at 30℃/80% RH was significantly higher than in any other conditions and near to 2 (Table 5), indicating that the humid environment was felt by the subjects and was having an impact on thermal sensation of the persons (p<0.05). Figure 5
Mean humidity sensation vote with different levels of air temperature and relative humidity.

sec.title: Humidity Preference
sec.p:
The humidity preference provides an indication of subjects’ requirements for their indoor environment. Figure 6 shows the results of humidity preference votes. The highest percentages of subjects indicated that they would like to reduce the humidity level were consistently shown when the subjects were exposed at 80% RH with all three air temperature conditions. The results with highest mean MHSV are shown in Figure 5. Moreover, at 30℃/80%RH, over 80% of votes (the highest percentage) of the subjects wanted to reduce the humidity level, which indicated that the high relative humidity would cause discomfort to people in indoor environment. Figure 6
Distribution of humidity preference in relation to air temperature and relative humidity.

sec.title: Thermal Comfort
sec.p:
Figure 7 shows the results of mean thermal comfort votes (MTCV). The MTCV at 80% RH was the lowest among all three air temperature levels. In addition, MTSV at 30℃/80% RH was near to 2, i.e. “uncomfortable”, the worst among all the conditions. Therefore high relative humidity in warm environment could cause discomfort sensation for the subjects. Figure 7
Mean thermal comfort vote with different levels of air temperature and relative humidity.

sec.title: Thermal Acceptability
sec.p:
Figure 8 shows the percentages of subjects who voted using the ASHRAE scale (−1, 0, +1) based on thermally acceptability of the environments [4]. At 80% RH, the lowest percentage of subjects felt the thermal environment was acceptable among all the experimental conditions. Moreover, at air temperature of 30℃ and 80% RH, only about 20% of the subjects would feel the thermal environment acceptable, in accordance with the results of MTSV and MTCV. Figure 8
Acceptability of thermal environment among all conditions.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: Relative humidity is an important factor that could affect thermal comfort. The above results obtained by this study, has inferred that a higher relative humidity in a warm environment could have a significant effect on physiological response of the subjects, and could affect the acceptance of the thermal environment.

In a warm environment, the heat loss by conduction and radiation is small. Instead, evaporation would be the main source of heat loss from the human body to its surrounding environment. Heat loss by evaporation is the vapour pressure difference between the body and its surrounding air. If the relative humidity is high, the vapour pressure difference would become small and evaporation of water is slow [37]. Thereby sufficient evaporation heat losses are not maintained. The temperature gradient between the body core temperature and skin temperature would become small [35]. The results of the present study have indicated that the MST would become higher and the MDLST would become lower as relative humidity was raised in the warm environment of the chamber study which supported this physiological response.

Moreover, the multiple comparisons of physiological response with different levels of air temperature and relative humidity have indicated that the higher humidity could provoke a higher sensation of warm sensation and a lower perception of humidity in warm environment.

Hence, in warm environment, the relative humidity should be an important parameter for the determination of acceptable thermal environment criteria. However, in ASHRAE standard 55-2010 [5], the allowable indoor operative temperature limit (80% acceptability) could be over 30℃ without any requirement for humidity. In many field studies in free-running buildings, there was insufficient consideration of the relative humidity effect on thermal sensation. If pooling all data given under different relative humidity to determine neutral temperature, the acceptable limit could show some discrepancy between theoretical results and real sensation.

The neutral temperature and allowable indoor operative temperature limits based on these field studies for naturally ventilated buildings around the world are summarised in Table 6. As in some studies [38,41,42], an acceptable air temperature at 80% RH based on field surveys can rise to about 30℃ while the air velocity was not too high. However, the acceptance of thermal environment at 30℃ was demonstrated by our experiments to decrease with an increase in relative humidity and at 80% RH, the acceptance was only about 20%. Furthermore, regression analysis was used to establish a model between TSV and indoor air temperature, and neutral temperature and the acceptable limit of temperature could be calculated by solving the regression model. Hence, the different thermal sensation reported under various relative humidity in warm environment could affect the accuracy of neutral temperature and the acceptance for air temperature. Table 6
Results of field studies for free-running buildings
Researcher Building Location Indoor RH range during survey (%) Air velocity (m/s) Neutral temperature (℃) Acceptable temperature limits at 80% RH (℃)
Li et al. [1] University dormitory buildings Chongqing, China 49–86 0.22 (mean in summer) 0.07 (mean in winter) 23.2 (Ta) 15.9–28.2 (Ta)
Wong and Khoo [38] Classroom Singapore 60–90 Not given 28.8 (Top) 27.1 – 29.3 (To)
Feriadi and Wong [39] Residential building Indonesia 50.8–87 0.1 (mean) 29.2 (Top) Not given
Han et. al. [40] Residential building Changsha Shenzhen, China 44.3–90 0.01–0.14 (mean) 28.6 (Ta) Not given
Ye et al. [41] Residential building, university apartments Shanghai, China Not given Less than 0.5 (95% of surveys) 27.0 (Top) in July 28.1 (Top) in Aug 14.7–29.8 (Top)
Wang et al. [42] Residential buildings Harbin, China 38.6–81.2 Less than 0.25 (94% of surveys) 23.7 (Ta) 21.5–31.0 (Ta)

In this study, the difference between the MTSV of 40% RH and 80% RH at 30℃ was 1.5 units based on the ASHRAE scale, and the difference between 60% RH and 80% RH was 1.1 units as shown in Figure 4. In the ASHRAE scale, there are only 6 units in the entire ASHRAE scale, the discrepancy of 1.5 units accounted for 25% of the entire ASHRAE scale, giving a huge deviation in the gradient of the regression line. Consequently, the huge deviation of the gradient could produce a chain reaction on the calculation of the neutral temperature and limits.

Furthermore, the de Dear regression model of the TSV versus indoor operative temperature [43] adopted by ASHRAE 55-2010 [5] would be taken as an example to analyse the impact. This regression curve and model are shown in Figure 9 and Table 7. If using TSV results under different relative humidity at 30℃ in this study to replace the results based on this model, an obvious variation in the gradient would be obtained. Thus, both the neutral indoor temperature and acceptability criteria at 80% RH would change respectively (Figure 9). The maximum difference in the acceptability criterion could be up to 5℃ and could cause a higher acceptance air temperature. Hence, the influence of high relative humidity on thermal sensation should be given sufficient consideration when determining the comfort range for both air conditioned and free-running buildings. Figure 9
Regression curve based on de Dear s model using different relative humidity. Table 7
Thermal neutrality temperature under different relative humidity conditions
Researcher Regression model Neutrality operative temperature (℃) 80% Acceptability criterion (℃)
de Dear [43] TSV = 0.27 Top − 6.65 24.6 6.3
This study (30℃/80% RH) TSV = 0.342 Top − 8.166 23.9 4.9
This study (30℃/60% RH) TSV = 0.22 Top − 5.6 25.5 7.7
This study (30℃/40% RH) TSV = 0.175 Top − 4.666 26.7 9.7

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: This study investigated the effect of relative humidity on human physiology and human thermal response of skin temperature in a warm environment in climatic chamber.

The physiological results showed that high relative humidity could cause an increase in the mean skin temperature, but would reduce the MDLST. The findings indicate that sufficient evaporation heat losses from the body surfaces are not maintained at higher humidity.

Subjective experiments showed that subjects were uncomfortable at higher humidity. About 80% of subjects could not accept the thermal environment of 30℃ and 80% RH, and 84% expressed a desire to reduce the humidity in the climatic chamber, illustrating the negative effect of higher humidity that could cause thermal discomfort on human subjects. To avoid negative effects, there should be a humidity limit set by the standards for the acceptable air temperature range for different indoor environments.

This study investigated a limited number of environmental conditions. Further studies are needed to investigate how relative humidity would quantitatively affect the thermal sensation of human occupants in warm environments.

ack.title: Acknowledgments
ack.p: This research study was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China under the research contract no. 50838009. The authors would like to thank all the subjects who participated in the experiments.
